content: I suggest you have a chat with the OWL folks. The lines would indicate to me that local copies of the files are simply not made. Given exchange takes attachments and stores them in a different location to the email they belong to. Got to love folk who treat an email store as a database and pull the email apart so different bits can be stored in their own tables. I would guess there is an issue with OWL, in how they access the attachments, or it might be you have to specifically download them to the email somehow..

content: Passwords are at settings>privacy&security - click 'saved passwords' and then 'show passwords' - This works only where the password is entered by you. In accounts such as Gmail that use app passwords, the password shown cannot be used again. Click 'account settings' to get email account info

content:
unless a folder is subscribed, Thunderbird acts as if it does not exist. That is really the point of the whole subscribe thing in my opinion.

Even then, certain folders, or example junk, are not checked unless you specifically include them in updates by right clicking the folder selecting properties and including the folder in checking mail.

content:
Create an exception in your anti-virus software for the Thunderbird profile folder, so that the anti-virus real-time scanner will not scan it. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/profiles-where-thunderbird-stores-user-data#w_how-to-find-your-profile

Does the problem go away?

content:
Hello there


For this topic if the sudden software freeze continues to occur.

Can you boot your PC Windows system in safe mode when in Safe mode of Windows you can boot the Thunderbird Software in trouble shoot mode.

If your email continues to respond in this way after your steps, you can also assume that there is an internal bug or virus.

If the problem no longer occurs when you run the Thunderbird program on your system as described above, you can now safely boot normally. And there was a program component missing that still needed to be installed.

This should be resolved after restarting from safe mode.


https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/troubleshoot-mode-thunderbird

Greetings Firefox volunteer
creator: googlethunderbird

content:
open the profile folder in a file manager.

Check for the existence of a prefs.js file. More importantly check for a load of them with numbers in them. IF they exist is is a symptom of Thunderbird failing to be able to save it's settings on shut down. The usual problem is an antivirus product poking around and getting all excited when it finds a .JS file (JavaScript). The solution is exclude the antivirus product form the profile folder.

There are other causes, just the antivirus is most common. Others include the disk space occupied by the prefs.js file being damaged so unable to be written. Chkdsk is the checker of choice on Windows. The power to the computer going out before the disk write on shutdown is complete can see setting not saved, but not the numbered files. This is generally folk turning off a power strip on their way out or some sort of all lights and power off switch that is flicked when the door is locked for the night.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: That error message usually happens when the profile was deleted or renamed. Your other screenshots imply that, although you can see it, you cannot load it. True? More details are usually helpful. Had you changed anything? If not, and if the profile cannot be loaded, an option is to exit Thunderbird, copy useful files (such as addressbook and message folders), and then create a new profile and copy the saved message files to Mail\local folders and the addressbook to the profile root, restart TB, and then recreate accounts.
creator: davidsk
